Chemical composition of CP1 provides information on the environment in which it was formed. The geodynamic setting in which serpentinites formed has significant influence on rock geochemistry
(Deschamps et al. 2013). The composition depends of the nature of fluids and temperature. Three groups of serpentinites are distinguished. Subduction zone- related serpentinite (De Hoog et al. 2009) is found mostly in suture zones associated with HP–LT meta- morphic rocks. Abyssal serpentinites (Jöns et al. 2010) represent oceanic peridotites altered by seawater. Mantle wedge serpentinites (Deschamps et al. 2010) are mantle peridotites altered by fluids released from the subducted slab.
According to Deschamps et al. (2013 and references therein), aqueous fluids in equilibrium with peridotites are enriched in SiO2 compared to MgO although this point remains controversial. But, additionally, the REE reflect the geochemical signature of the original proto- lith because these elements are little mobile during serpentinization.

5.2. Zircon U–Pb–Hf isotopes and trace elements
The study of zircon from the CP3 rodingite blackwall, using multiple techniques, indicates three main age groups, namely 793 ± 0.9, 757 ± 2.1, and 715 ± 2.2 Ma. The analysed neoproterozoic zircon grains have Hf-model age = 0.91– 0.74, corresponding to a rock-section of juvenile signature (?Hf = +10.7 to +15). These compositions are coeval with São Gabriel terrane ophiolites (?Hf = +8 to +15 and Hf TDM = 1.23–0.75 Ga; Arena et al. 2016). Integrated evalua- tion of U–Pb age and trace elements with the Hf-model age and depleted mantle ?Hf shows that the zircons evolved from a ~ 793 Ma mantle. This array of data is attributed to three continued pulses of serpentinization. The 176Hf/177Hf ratios of all analysed zircons are effectively identical (0.282649–0.282748) (Gerdes and Zeh 2009; Vervoort and Kemp 2016), indicating that zircons from the ophiolite have a single Hf isotopic composition.
The trace element analyses of U and Yb exhibit compatibility in magmatic systems according to Grimes et al. (2007, 2009). HREEs (e.g. Yb) as well as Hf and Y concentrations are enriched in MORB relative to continental crust. The REEs are similar to the São Gabriel terrane ophiolites (Figure 11(a)). The affinity of zircon with U, Yb, and other HREEs permits these ele- ments to be incorporated into zircon such that the U/ Yb ratios of zircon reflects the chemical environment of crystallization. Additional phases crystallizing with zir- con (e.g. xenotime) (Figure 8(a–e)) likely compete for U

Because of the occurrence of ultramafic rocks (Marques et al. 2003) and of mafic and felsic metavol- canic rocks with negative to slightly negative ?Nd values (Gollmann et al. 2008), the Capané region was previously discussed separately from the Porongos fold and thrust belt and interpreted as the basal section of an ophiolite (Marques et al. 1998). A metarhyolite from the Capané antiform with U–Pb SHRIMP age of 783 ± 6 Ma was dated by Porcher et al. (1999) and interpreted as the age of crystallization. Also, zircon U–Pb SHRIMP ages for a Capané chlorite schist indi- cated two populations. One Neoproterozoic population is 800–570 Ma old, and a Palaeo to Mesoproterozoic population is 2250–1200 Ma. Both populations derived from recycled crust, showing sources (Pertille et al. 2015a) with ?Hf between ?18 and ?4 and Hf TDM = 2.2–1.5 Ga (Figure 10).
In the Porongos fold and thrust belt, U–Pb (TIMS) ages of zircons from a meta-andesite in the Santana area are 783 ± 8 Ma (Chemale 2000). Metavolcanic rocks from the Porongos Group were also studied by Saalmann et al. (2006). The isotopic data led these authors to recognize two distinct groups. In the north- western region, ?Nd(t = 780 Ma) values are between ?20.6 and ?21.7, and in the southeastern region ?Nd (t = 780) is close to ?6.9. The high 87Sr/86Sr(i) values (0.7064–0.7286) and trace element data support the interpretation of partial melting or considerable con- tamination by old continental crust during magma gen- eration and evolution. A U–Pb rhyolite zircon age of 789 ± 7 Ma obtained by Saalmann et al. (2011) was indicated as crystallization age. The continental origin for the Tonian zircon grains (809, 801, 773 Ma) from rhyodacites of Porongos fold and thrust belt was also recently detected by Lu–Hf (?Hf = ?20 and ?10; Hf
TDM = 2.18–1.77 Ga) and ? 18O (7.8 and 9.7 ‰) by
Pertille et al. (2017). A rift setting around 800 Ma was suggested by
Saalmann et al. (2011) for the Porongos Group, formed over the Encantadas basement. But ages of a mag- matic event from 802 to 767 Ma were also recognized within the Dom Feliciano Belt. In the Rocha region, Uruguay (Cerro Bori Orthogneisses), in Piratini region (mafic xenoliths, Piratini Gneiss) and in granitoids in the Porto Alegre region (Chácara das Pedras Orthogneiss), rocks show subduction-related continen- tal magmatic arc affinity (Silva et al. 1999; Lenz et al. 2011; Koester et al. 2016).
The contact between the Porongos Group and the Pelotas Batholith is delimited by the Dorsal de Canguçu Shear Zone (e.g. Hartmann et al. 2016 and references therein) (Figure 1(b)). Several authors consider this shear zone a suture (e.g. Fragoso-César et al. 1986; Saalmann et al. 2011) or intra-continental fault (Fernandes and Koester 1999). Therefore, the origin of Dorsal de Canguçu shear zone and associated environ- ment are a subject of controversy. Zircons close to 800 Ma may be either part of thrust slices or detrital, originated in either case from the Pelotas Batholith.
The youngest possible age for Capané ophiolite obduction is 715 Ma. During the advance of the fold and thrust belt, parts of ophiolites remained near the roots of the thrust, e.g. the Arroio Grande ophiolite (surrounded by Pelotas Batholith) and parts were thrusted into the Porongos fold and thrust belt, e.g. Capané ophiolite (Figure 12). The thrust wedges were progressively deformed in the depositional zones, thus forming the Porongos and Camaquã basins (Figure 12).
After Gondwana stabilization and the end of oro- geny, orogenic wedge migration ceased in the Sul- Riograndense Shield (Figure 12). This model inserts the evolution of the ophiolite into the proposal for the Porongos fold and thrust belt by Saalmann et al. (2006) and Pertille et al. (2017). Our model explains the presence of an ophiolite within a continental schist belt

(Figures 2 and 3) and uses the presence of the ophiolite to propose a new scenario for the evolution of the Brasiliano Orogen in its southern segment.
The Capané ophiolite emplacement was related to the development of the Brasiliano Orogenic Cycle. Ophiolite obduction occurred during ocean closure. This event was coeval with ophiolite emplacement in the juvenile São Gabriel terrane, in the western portion of the Dom Feliciano Belt. The emplacement age in the western terrane was interpreted as approximately 722 Ma at the end of a protracted evolution of the ophiolite during 880–722 Ma (Arena et al. 2017). Similar and coeval processes occurred in the western and eastern portions of the Dom Feliciano Belt. The continental collision between the Rio the La Plata and Kalahari Cratons that fol- lowed the final closure of the Adamastor ocean is recorded the metamorphic events (650–620 Ma) and in emplacement of the Pelotas Batholith (Philipp et al. 2016a).
With the erosional decay after tectonic convergence and interruption of crustal thickening, there occurred the continued post-orogenic development of a moun- tain range and its foreland as proposed by Tucker and Van Der Beek (2013) and Pertille et al. (2017). The suture zone of a mountain belt is a fundamental structure inherited from subduction and indicates the contact of passive margin rocks with terrane or accretionary wedge material. This zone also contains deformed rocks that were thrusted together (Van Der Pluijm and Marshak 1997). This zone in this work is signalled by the displaced Capané ophiolite indicating an active conti- nental margin collision on the eastern portion of the Dom Feliciano Belt, related to the Brasiliano cycle.
6. Conclusions
The mantle section of the Capané ophiolite is a piece of depleted mantle, presently occurring in the Porongos fold and thrust belt. Zircon from a rodingite blackwall, contained in serpentinite, yields ?Hf between +10.7 and + 15.0, with trace element composition similar to deri- vation from depleted mantle. This overall composition indicates that zircon is related to melt batches origi- nated in the depleted mantle. The U–Pb dating of the zircon from this ophiolite at 793 ± 0.9 to 715 ± 2.2 Ma in the Dom Feliciano Belt, southern Brasiliano Orogen, sets a limit to the tectonic evolution of West Gondwana involving the amalgamation of the Rio de la Plata and Kalahari cratons and closure of Adamastor Ocean. The ophiolite marks the final closure of the ocean preceding the formation of a mountain belt. The obduction
occurred during the collision that formed the Porongos fold and thrust belt at 650–570 Ma.

Abstract: The isotopic and geochemical evolution of tourmaline constrain the evolution of paleo- oceanic lithosphere in ophiolites. The Brasiliano Orogen is a major structure of South America and requires characterization for the understanding of Gondwana supercontinent evolution. We made a pioneering investigation of tourmaline from a tourmalinite in the Ibaré ophiolite by integrating field work with chemical analyses of tourmaline by electron microprobe (EPMA) and ?11B determinations via laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (LA-ICP-MS). Remarkably massive tourmalinite (>90 vol.% tourmaline, some chlorite) enclosed in serpentinite has homogeneous dravite in chemical and isotopic composition (?11B = +3.5 to +5.2‰). These results indicate a geotectonic environment in the altered oceanic crust for the origin of the tourmalinite. This first ?11B characterization of tourmaline from tourmalinite sets limits to the evolution of the Neoproterozoic Brasiliano Orogen and Gondwana evolution.

Introduction 36
Tourmaline is a most useful mineral because it is robust and can retain a record 37
of geological processes (van Hinsberg et al. 2011). The mineral is helpful for the 38
understanding of both continental (Chaussidon and Albarède 1992; Trumbull et al. 39
2008; Cabral et al. 2017) and oceanic (Smith et al. 1995; Farber et al. 2015) settings. 40
Most studies focused on accessory tourmaline in granitic and volcanic-41
sedimentary rocks, in addition to sulphide ore (e.g., Namaqualand, South Africa - 42
Plimer 1987; Sullivan, British Columbia – Palmer and Slack 1989; Broken Hill, 43
Australia – Slack et al. 1993). Fewer studies concentrated on oceanic lithosphere, 44
including crust and mantle or unravelling of volatile transfer processes from the 45
subduction setting to the mantle wedge and to arc magmatism (Palmer 1991; Rosner et 46
al. 2003; Savov et al. 2005; Boschi et al. 2008; Yamaoka et al. 2012). In Brazil, 47
stratiform tourmalinite occurs associated to mineralized quartz-tourmaline vein in the 48
Mesoproterozoic Serra do Itaberaba (Ribeira belt, SE Brazil - Garda et al. 2009). 49
Tourmaline was also described in pegmatites (Borborema Province, NE Brazil – 50
3
Trumbull et al. 2013) and as platiniferous gold–tourmaline aggregates (Gold–palladium 51
belt of Minas Gerais, Brazil – Cabral et al. 2017). 52
Tourmaline (geochemistry, ?11B) was only studied in continental rocks in the 53
continent. In the Brasiliano Orogen, Neoproterozoic ophiolites were only studied with 54
zircon U-Pb isotopes in the Araçuaí Belt (oceanic plagiogranite – Queiroga et al. 2007) 55
and Dom Feliciano Belt (albitite, chloritite, tourmalinite, rodingite blackwall – Arena et 56
al. 2016, 2017a, b). Tourmalines from ophiolites were not studied. 57
We selected a massive tourmalinite (>90 vol.% tourmaline) from southern 58
Brazil, because the rock is part of the Ibaré ophiolite. The sample was previously 59
investigated with zircon U-Pb-Hf isotopes by Arena et al. (2017a). Large (5-30 m 60
diameter) tourmalinites remain undescribed in the oceanic crust or ophiolites, so this is 61
a pioneering investigation of mantle interaction with oceanic water in the Tonian. 62
The tourmalinite was described in the field and large tourmaline crystals (up to 63
10 cm) were studied by EPMA for major elements and LA-ICP-MS for ?11B. The 64
results indicate a remarkably homogeneous dravite, including boron isotopes (?11B = 65
+3.5 to +5.2‰). We interpret the tourmalinite as formed in the Tonian oceanic crust by 66
alteration of mantle rocks in contact with oceanic water. This characterization of the 67
geotectonic environment may have large impact on studies of the Brasiliano Orogen in 68
the continent and reconstruction of Rodinia and Gondwana. 69
70
Geological setting 71
The Ibaré ophiolite from the São Gabriel terrane is part of the Dom Feliciano 72
Belt, southern Brasiliano Orogen (Figs. 1a, b). The formation of the Dom Feliciano Belt 73
involved the closure of the Adamastor Ocean. Corresponding subduction events resulted 74
in the development of two intra-oceanic arcs in the São Gabriel terrane at the pre- 75
4
collisional stage of the Brasiliano orogenic cycle (Machado et al. 1990; Leite et al. 76
1998; Remus et al. 1999; Gubert et al. 2016; Arena et al. 2017a) with subsequent 77
ophiolite emplacement (Arena et al. 2016, 2017a). The Capané ophiolite occurs in the 78
eastern portion of Dom Feliciano Belt (Fig. 1b) and has similar age to the São Gabriel 79
terrane (e.g., Arena et al. 2017b). This ophiolite was emplaced into the Porongos fold 80
and thrust belt (Pertille et al. 2015, 2017). 81
The main geological units of the São Gabriel terrane formed early in the 82
Brasiliano Orogen (948 Ma to 660 Ma; Chemale et al. 1995; Babinski et al. 1996; Leite 83
et al. 1998; Saalmann et al. 2005a, b; Hartmann et al. 2011; Lena et al. 2014; Lopes et 84
al. 2015; Arena et al. 2016). The studied tourmalinite is part of the Ibaré ophiolite 85
(Arena et al. 2017a), associated with volcano-sedimentary rocks which are remnants of 86
a Neoproterozoic intra-oceanic arc. 87
The Ibaré ophiolite and associated rocks (Figs. 1b, 2a) show evidence of 88
regional greenschist facies metamorphism strongly overprinted by contact 89
metamorphism caused by the intrusion (Naumann and Hartmann 1984; Naumann 1985) 90
of the Santa Rita Granite (584.7 ± 1.9 Ma - Arena et al. 2017a). Zircon U-Pb-Hf 91
isotopic and geochemical characteristics of the Ibaré tourmalinite (Arena et al. 2017a) 92
indicate the beginning of metasomatism at 880 Ma, culminating with the ophiolite 93
emplacement at 722 Ma into intra-oceanic arc in subduction-zone setting along the 94
margins of the Rio de la Plata craton. 95
96
Sample description 97
Within the Ibaré ophiolite, massive tourmalinite (>90 vol.% tourmaline) is 98
associated with chloritite, serpentinite, magnesian schist, rodingite, and albitite 99
(Naumann 1985; Arena et al. 2016, 2017a). Santa Rita Granite intruded the ophiolite in 100
5
the northern portion and a small plug of the Jaguari Granite in the southern portion. The 101
studied tourmalinite (2 x 5 m large) occurs immersed in chloritite and serpentinite (Figs. 102
2b, c). Black color of tourmalinite is distinctive and contrasts with serpentinite and the 103
surrounding chloritite blackwall. The tourmalinite is composed of tourmaline, chlorite, 104
some ilmenite and zircon. 105

Analytical methods 107
Field study of the Ibaré ophiolite included collection of selected tourmalinite 108
IB14 sample. Petrography of the tourmalinite preceded the determination of chemical 109
and boron isotopic analyses of tourmaline. Petrography was done with a transmission 110
petrographic microscope Olympus BX51, UC30. One polished thin section of the 111
sample was studied for elemental mapping of tourmaline by electron microprobe at 112
Laboratório de Microssonda Eletrônica, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul. A 113
block was cut from the massive tourmalinite sample (Figs. 2d, e) and measures 10 cm in 114
length by ~1.5 cm in width. The block was divided into parts and placed in 5 mounts in 115
sequential order, each measuring 2 cm x 1.5 cm (Fig. 2f). Mounts from tablets 3 and 4 116
(Figs. 2f, 3a, b) were selected for analyses by scanning electron microprobe and boron 117
isotopes at Departamento de Geologia, Universidade Federal de Ouro Preto (UFOP), 118
Minas Gerais. All these spot analyses were controlled by backscattered electron images 119
(Fig. 3). 120
121
Electron Microprobe 122
Electron microprobe analyses of mounted tourmalines were performed at UFOP 123
using a JEOL JXA-8230 Superprobe equipped with 5 spectrometers. Operating 124
conditions were 15 kV accelerating voltage, 20 nA beam current and 10 ?m beam 125
6
diameter and a selection of measurement spots ensured that the stimulated volume was 126
not contaminated by phases other than tourmaline. Counting times on the 127
peaks/background were 10/5 s for all elements. Background intensities were collected at 128
higher and lower energies relative to the corresponding K? line. Appropriate natural and 129
synthetic reference materials were used for calibration (Online Appendix 1). 130
Tourmaline structural formulae were calculated by normalizing to 15 cations in the 131
tetrahedral and octahedral sites (T + Z + Y) and assuming 3 boron apfu (Henry et al. 132
2011) using the Excel spreadsheet of Tindle et al. (2002). 133
134
Boron isotopes 135
Boron isotope ratio measurements were carried out at UFOP on a Thermo-Scientific 136
Neptune Plus multi-collector ICP-MS coupled to a Photon Machines 193 Excimer laser 137
ablation system. Samples were abladed in He atmosphere using 20 um diameter spot 138
and 15 Hz frequency at 7 J/cm2. In the mass spectrometer, 10B and 11B intensities were 139
measured (in low resolution) on the L2 and H2 detectors, respectively. The 140
measurements consisted of 98 cycles (or integration) and 0.5 s of integration time. Data 141
were processed after the daily run using an in-house spreadsheet by A. Gerdes (e.g., 142
Devulder et al. 2015). The measured, background signal of the unknown sample was 143
corrected for instrumental mass fractionation (IMF) using a standard-sample bracketing 144
method and tourmaline B4 (schorl, ?11B = -8.62 ‰) (Tonarini et al. 2003) as the 145
primary reference material. The drift-corrected ratios were referenced to the published 146
11B/10B value of the reference material and the results are reported as ?11B values 147
relative to NIST SRM 951 boric acid using the certified 11B/10B value of 4.04362 ± 148
0.00137 (Catanzaro et al. 1970). Matrix effects, known to occur in B isotope 149
measurements (e.g., Mikova et al. 2014) and the reproducibility of the data were 150
7
monitored during the analyses using dravite (#108796) and elbaite (#98144) (Leeman 151
and Tonarini 2001) as external reference material (Online Appendix 2). The observed 152
internal precision for individual analyses varied between 0.3 and 0.9‰. 153
154
Results 155
Representative electron microprobe analyses of tourmaline are listed in Online 156
Appendix 3. All analyzed points (n = 60) in tourmaline showed chemical homogeneity. 157
We made 21 analyses in two basal sections of individual tourmaline grains (Figs. 3c, d), 158
11 random tourmaline analyses (Fig. 3d) and 28 analyses along a tourmaline of 159
approximately 20 mm length (Fig. 3e). They show a range in MgO from 7.16 to 8.64 160
wt.%, FeO from 6.25 to 7.76 wt.%; CaO from 0.22 to 0.49 wt.% and Na2O from 2.54 to 161
2.80 wt.%. 162
The basic formula of tourmaline can be written as XY3Z6 (T6O18)(BO3) V3W, 163
where X = Na, Ca, K, vacancy; Y = Fe2+, Mg, Mn2+, Li, Al, Cr3+, V3+, Fe3+, Ti4+; Z = 164
Mg, Al, Fe3+, V3+,Cr3+; T = Si, Al, (B); V = OH, O; W = OH, F, O (Hawthorne and 165
Henry, 1999). Chemical substitutions in tourmaline occur mainly in the X, Y and Z sites 166
(Henry and Guidotti 1985). Some Al defficiency (<6 atoms per formula unit) in the Z 167
site is due to Mg substitution and no Fe3+. In addition, the X site occupancy is 168
predominantly Na. The tourmaline is close dravite in composition (Online Appendix 3). 169
Tourmalines show no chemical zoning (e.g., Fig. 4). Tourmalines are of alkali group 170
(Na + K dominant at X site) and Mg-rich (Figs. 5a, b). The array is most consistent with 171
operation of the MgFe2+?1 substitution (Figs. 6a, b). 172
The studied IB14 tourmalines show homogenous isotopic compositions ranging 173
from ?11B = +3.5 to +5.2‰ (Fig. 8b, Table 1). 174

Discussion 176
Dravite from Ibaré tourmalinite (IB14 sample) is Mg-rich and shows 177
homogeneous chemistry and isotopic composition, ?11B = +3.5 to +5.2‰. Because 178
tourmalinites may also form during regional and contact metamorphism, careful 179
evaluation is necessary to determine their origin relative to hydrothermal, metamorphic 180
and granitic process. Particular care is required for the identification of processes in the 181
oceanic realm. 182
A previous study of metasomatic zircon from sample IB14 indicated positive 183
?Hf = +12.06 to +4.54 over time, a signature interpreted as MORB fluid source (Arena 184
et al. 2017a). Most intense processes of zircon formation occurred at 722 Ma. 185
The Jaguari (569 ± 6 Ma; Gastal et al. 2015) and Santa Rita (584.7 ± 1.9 Ma; 186
Arena et al. 2017a) granites (Fig. 2) were possible sources in case tourmalinization 187
occurred in the continent, after the emplacement of the ophiolite. Our results discard 188
this hypothesis. Tourmaline in most granites and pegmatites in the continents has ?11B 189
values close to average continental crust (?11B = ?10 ±3‰; Marschall and Jiang 2011). 190
Besides, tourmaline compositions in granitic rocks plot in fields 1 to 3 (Figs. 7a, b). In 191
contrast, IB14 tourmalines plot in field 6 on Al–Fe–Mg(total) and Ca-Fe-Mg(total) 192
diagrams (Henry and Guidotti 1985), unrelated to granitic rocks. 193
Chemistry of tourmalinite from seafloor volcano-exhalative activity (Beljavskis 194
et al. 2005) shows that distal tourmalines plot into field 6 and proximal tourmalines 195
overlap fields 2, 4 and 5 (Fig. 7a). In Figure 7b, distal tourmalines plot in field 7 196
reflecting high CaO content. Boron isotope compositions of tourmaline (Garda et al. 197
2009) in Ribeira belt tourmalinites previously studied by Beljavskis et al. (2005), 198
showed ?11B = ?7.51 to ?14.58‰. This evidences chemical and isotopic differences 199
from the Ibaré tourmalinite (Figs 7a, b, 8b). 200
9
Tourmalines from Borborema pegmatites (Trumbull et al. 2013) overlap fields 5 201
and 6 on Al–Fe–Mg diagram (Fig. 7a); on Ca-Fe-Mg diagram (Fig. 7b), they overlap 202
fields 1, 2 and 6 because of their preserved source chemical signature from surrounding 203
rocks. The full range of ?11B is ?20.2 to +1.6‰ with main range ?17 to ?9‰ (Fig. 8b). 204
Trumbull et al. (2013) suggest that the strong isotopic contrast between the main range 205
and the heavy B resulted from mixing with enclosing marble and calc-silicate rocks. It 206
is significant that the origin of IB14 tourmaline was unrelated to granitic fluids. Ibaré 207
tourmaline is Mg-rich but no associated sedimentary or exhalative rocks were identified. 208
Tourmalines from many environments are strongly zoned and varied in trace elements 209
and boron isotopes, but IB14 tourmaline is chemically homogeneous (Figs. 4, 7, 8). The 210
uniformity in composition of IB14 tourmalines is highlighted by comparison with 211
tourmalines from tourmalinites associated with augen gneiss, leucogranite and garnet-212
micaschist (Fig. 7a, b) (Menderes Massif, Turkey - Yücel-Öztürk et al. 2015). 213
In hydrothermal systems (Slack et al. 1993), Mg-rich tourmalines may form either by 214
pre-metamorphic replacement from seawater-derived fluids under high fluid/rock 215
conditions, or by sulfide-silicate reactions during metamorphism. Our results are more 216
consistent with seawater-derived fluids. The IB14 dravites are interpreted as formed 217
from entrained seawater (Slack and Trumbull 2011) (Fig. 7c) which caused 218
serpentinization and subsequent tourmalinization. 219
The IB14 dravite has boron isotope composition (?11B = + 3.5 to +5.2 ‰) 220
typical of blackwall metasomatism between altered oceanic crust and serpentinite. The 221
tourmalinite formed below the seawater-sediment (or volcanic) interface with no 222
exhalative component (closely associated or in contact with chemical sediments such as 223
metachert and iron-formation) as described by Slack et al. (1993). This is in agreement 224
with the values of modern bulk oceanic crust (Fig. 8a) by Farber et al. (2015), which 225
10
ranges between +3.7‰ and +7.9‰ (Smith et al. 1995; Yamaoka et al. 2015). The B 226
isotope composition of IB14 tourmalinite is more enriched in ?11B than the slab 227
materials from which they likely originated (?11B MORB = ?3‰ to ?14‰, average 228
?7.1‰; Chaussidon and Jambon 1994; Marschall et al. 2017). This enrichment 229
indicates that hydrothermal marine fluids altered bulk oceanic crust in the Ibaré 230
tourmalinite. The boron concentration of fresh MORB has a ?11B value of ?7‰, but 231
when circulating seawater interacts with ocean crust at ~100 °C, then the boron is taken 232
up into secondary minerals. Compilations of ocean cores and ophiolite sections give 233
average boron contents of ?11B = +3‰ for the upper oceanic crust (Smith et al. 1995) 234
and the upper mantle may be altered to serpentinite by circulating seawater, particularly 235
at slow-spreading mid-ocean ridges (Palmer 2017). 236
The boron isotope composition of the oceanic crust is the result of crust 237
interaction with seawater, through capture of boron during hydrothermal alteration 238
(Spivack and Edmond 1987; Smith et al. 1995). The average ?11B calculated for altered 239
oceanic crust is +3.7‰ (Smith et al. 1995) while serpentinite shows ?11B values ranging 240
between +8 (Boschi et al. 2008) and +15.1‰ (Benton et al. 2001). An increase in heavy 241
?11B values (+20‰; Harvey et al. 2014) occurs by interaction with hot hydrothermal 242
fluids at low pH in deeper levels of the oceanic crust (Seyfried and Ding 1995). 243
Tourmaline from some geological settings may carry B enriched in 11B (Table 2). 244
The range in sediments is typically negative (except carbonates from +13.3‰ to 245
+31.9‰, Hemming and Ho?nisch 2007). The older marine sediments analyzed by 246
Ishikawa and Nakamura (1993) showed ?11B values between ?17‰ and ?5.6‰, 247
systematically lower than modern sediments. 248
An evaluation is made of the mobility of boron in subduction-zone 249
environments to test the hypotheses of origin of Ibaré tourmalinite. Boron isotopes can 250
11
be used to unravel transfer processes from the subducting oceanic crust to the mantle 251
wedge and to arc magmatism (Palmer 1991; Ishikawa and Tera 1999; Rosner et al. 252
2003; Savov et al. 2005). Studies by Ishikawa and Tera (1999) suggested a central role 253
of altered oceanic crust and sediments as sources of fluids and boron in subduction 254
zones. Additionally, Savov et al. (2005) and Tonarini et al. (2007) showed the potential 255
role of subducted serpentinites as an important source of B-rich fluids to supra-256
subduction setting. Peacock and Hervig (1999) suggest that subduction-zone 257
metamorphic dehydration reactions decrease the ?11B value of subducted altered 258
oceanic crust as well as subducted sediments through continuous dehydration reactions 259
(Table 2). Boron uptake in oceanic rocks occurs by direct incorporation of boron during 260
crystallization of structurally favorable, B-rich hydrothermal-diagenetic minerals 261
(phyllosilicates - Williams et al. 2001) or by adsorption from seawater by secondary 262
minerals such as clays and during low-temperature interaction of fluids with crustal, 263
mantle and sedimentary rocks (You et al. 1996). Chemical and boron isotopic 264
characteristics of subduction-zone mobility of elements were not observed in Ibaré 265
samples. 266
The isotopic and geochemical characteristics of IB14 dravite indicate parental 267
fluid sourced from seawater. Lithospheric mantle was intensely metasomatised by large 268
volumes of fluids during associated serpentinization (Fig. 8b). The characteristic 269
depleted mantle composition of zircon contained in the tourmalinite and chloritite 270
(Arena et al. 2017a) supports the derivation of studied tourmaline from altered oceanic 271
crust. 272
We envisage a geological history of the Ibaré ophiolite starting with oceanic 273
crust formation in the Tonian during initial rupturing of Rodinia. Intense alteration of 274
oceanic crust and mantle by interaction with heated oceanic water produced an 275
12
association of serpentinite, chloritite blackwall and massive tourmalinite. This 276
association was later accreted to an island-arc with little additional alteration of the 277
tourmaline, which remained homogeneous in chemistry and boron isotopes. The 278
characterization of the paleo-oceanic crust and mantle in the Ibaré ophiolite through the 279
study of tourmalinite is most useful for the understanding of processes related to 280
Rodinia rupturing and Gondwana assembly. 281
282
Conclusion 283
Dravite with no chemical zoning and with homogeneous isotopic composition 284
(?11B = +3.5 to +5.2‰.) strengthens previous studies of mantle origin for intensely 285
metasomatized Ibaré ophiolite. Tourmalines originated during formation of 286
Neoproterozoic Brasiliano Orogen in oceanic altered crust prior to subduction and 287
ophiolite obduction. Characterization of tourmalinite in Ibaré ophiolite is important to 288
interpretations of geodynamic evolution of the southern Brasiliano Orogen. 289
